intro: Herpestis procumbens, commonly known as the creeping false nettle, is a low-growing perennial plant native to North America. It belongs to the family Urticaceae, which includes true nettles, and is characterized by its opposite, ovate leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in clusters, which are typically borne on slender, erect stalks. Its stems are covered in fine hairs, and the leaves often have a slight pubescence. Herpestis procumbens is often found in moist, disturbed soils along streambanks and woodland edges.
